Airlift API Documentation

Airlift is an open web framework for building restful web applications using functional JavaScript on Google App Engine.


Users new to Airlift should check out the manual to get started. This API should help to clarify functions and assist the user as he writes his applications. The Airlift API provides method signatures, descriptions, working code examples and more for each available function in Airlift.

Color coded labels denote the stability of the function and tells in which version the function was added. The stability index is given as follows:


Experimental: This function is newly released. It may be changed or removed in the future. Feedback on this function would be greatly appreciated.
Stable: This is a fully supported and robustly tested function. Future versions of Airlift will strive to maintain backwards compatibility.
Unstable: This function may still be subject to revisions.
Deprecated: This function will be removed in future versions of Airlift. Backwards compatibility should not be expected. Avoiding futher usage is highly recommended.

This project is hosted on Github.

The PDF of this documentation can be downloaded here.

Extensions

JavaScript module extensions that support Airlift utility modules.

Airlift is built on Rhino and App Engine. Rhino is a fantastic JavaScript interpreter library written for Java. App Engine is a fantastic platform as a service cloud environment that offers support for web applications programmed in Go, Python, and Java.

In order for Airlift to support server side JavaScript programming on App Engine we applied Rhino’s capabilities to the App Engine environment. To accomplish this we extended some of Rhino’s libraries, and we added additional functionality to JavaScript’s standard objects. The following outlines the adaptations and improvements we made.

Function.prototype.partial (argument-1, argument-2, …, argument-n)

Return type: Object

Returns a wrapper function that wraps the function refered to by 'this'. The arguments passed into partial are stored to be applied when the wrapper function is invoked. When the wrapper function is invoked, its arguments are tacked on to the stored arguments. If any of stored arguments are undefined, they will be filled in in the order of presentation of the wrapper function arguments. 

 var f0 = function(a1, a2)
      {
           return a1 + a2;
      };
 var f1 = f0.partial(undefined, 'Bediako');	
 => Hello Bediako

String.prototype.equalsIgnoreCase (java.lang.String|String string)

Return type: boolean

Case insensitive comparison of a JavaScript string1 to another JavaScript or Java string. Added as a convenience method, equalsIgnoreCase is merely a wrapper for java.lang.String.equalsIgnoreCase. 

 var string1 = 'bediako';
 var string2 = new Packages.java.lang.String('Bediako');
 string1.equalsIgnoreCase(string2);
 => true

String.prototype.replaceAll (java.lang.String|String string1, java.lang.String|String string2)

Return Type: String

Replaces every occurrence of 'string1' in 'this' with 'string2'. Added as a convenience method, replaceAll is merely a wrapper for java.lang.String.replaceAll. 

 var string1 = 'banana';
 string1.replaceAll('na', '');
 => 'ba'

String.prototype.contains(java.lang.String|String string)

Return Type: boolean

Returns true if 'this' contains 'string'. 

 var string1 = 'banana';
 string1.contains('na');
 => true

JSON.prototype.stringify()

Return Type: String

Will stringify JavaScript objects as determined by EcmaScript standard as well as stringify the following Java objects ... all Java primitives and all Java primitive arrays; java.util.Date, java.lang.String, java.lang.Number, java.lang.Character, java.lang.Byte and their associated arrays; java.util.Collection and java.util.Map of all the aforementioned primitives, primitive arrays, objects, and object arrays. 

var list = new Packages.java.util.ArrayList();
list.add('Bediako');
JSON.stringify(list);
=> ['Bediako']

Resource

The resource module contains functions that allow you to iterate over the attributes of your application's resources.

Airlift is a restful framework. Resources are the center of Airlift application development. When designing an application, developers are encouraged to create as many resources as they like. The resource.js module contains functions that allow developers to traverse the application resources’ attributes. In Airlift a resource is represented as a simple JavaScript object ({}).

Whenever a iterative function is executed in resource, the iterator function that you provide is executed within a context that governs the traversal of that resource. This context is set as the ‘this’ for the iterator function. It makes available following:

  • resourceName - the name of the resource being traversed.
  • resourceMetadata - metadata describing the resource being traversed. It contains a list of attributes this resource holds.
  • attributesMetadata - metadata describing each individual attribute this resource holds.
  • foreignKeys - a list of names of all the foreign keys in this resource.
  • attributes - a list of names of all the attributes in this resource.
  • web - a web object that gives access to the web context. The web context contains information about the current request.
  • report - a function used to report errors.
  • allErrors - a function that returns all errors reported so far.
  • getErrors - a function that returns all errors reported for a given attribute of this resource.

All iterative functions in resource.js allow for the replacement of any of the attributes of the context object by optionally providing an object at invocation time.

The functions available in this module are described below. They can be accessed by providing the following code:

 var resource = require('airlift/resource');

each(String resourceName, Object resource, Function function, Function callback, Object context)

Return Type: n/A

Iterates over a resource, yielding each in turn to an iterator function. The iterator is bound to the context object, if one is passed, along with the attributes provided in the default context. Each invocation of iterator is called with four arguments: value, attributeName, resource, and metadata. An optional callback can be supplied. If the callback is supplied, it will be called at the end of the iteration cycle with two arguments: resourceName, resource. 

 var attributes = [];

 resource.each('person', bediako, 
       function iterator(_value, _attributeName, _resource, _metadata)
           {
                attributes.push(_attributeName);		
           },
       function callback(_resourceName, resource)
           {
                attributes.push('finished');
           }, context);

 => ["fullName", "shortName", "status", "birthDate", "id", "finished"]

map(String resourceName, Object resource, Function function, Function callback, Object context)

Return type: Object

Iterates over a resource, yielding each in turn to an iterator function. The iterator is bound to the context object, if one is passed, along with the attributes provided in the default context. Each invocation of iterator is called with four arguments: value, attributeName, resource, and metadata. The result of each iterator invocation is saved to a new resource object. 

 var attributes = [];

 //create a person resource using map ...
 var person = resource.map('person', bediako,
     function(_value, _attributeName, _resource, _metadata)
     {
         attributes.push(_attributeName);
     return _value;
     }, undefined, context);

 => ["fullName","shortName","status","birthDate","age","friendList","familySet",
     "auditPostDate","auditPutDate","auditUserId","id"]

transform(Object dictionary, String resourceName, Object resource, Function function, Function callback, Object context)

Return type: Object

Transforms the attribute names of a resource into a new set of names as defined by the 'dictionary'. 

 var attributes = [];
 var bediako = {fullName: 'Bediako George', shortName: 'Bediako', 
      status: 'middle aged', id: 1};
 var dictionary = {fullName: 'name'};

 //create a person resource using transform ...
 resource.transform(dictionary, 'person', bediako,
     function(_value, _attributeName, _resource, _metadata)
     {
           attributes.push(_attributeName);
           return _value;
     }, undefined, context);

 => {name: 'Bediako George', shortName: 'Bediako', status: 'middle aged', id: 1}

reduce(String base, String resourceName, Object resource, Function function, Function callback, Object context)

Return type: String

Iterates over a resource, yielding each in turn to an iterator function. The iterator is bound to the context object, if one is passed, along with the attributes provided in the default context. Each invocation of iterator is called with five arguments: base, value, attributeName, resource, and metadata. The result of each iterator invocation replaces the base value. Reduce returns the value of base at the end. 

 var attributes = [];
 	
 var reducedResult = resource.reduce('person:', 'person', bediako,
      function(_base, _value, _attributeName, _resource, _metadata)
      {
           attributes.push(_attributeName);
           var formattedValue = Packages.airlift.util.FormatUtil.format(_value||"");
           return _base + ':' + _attributeName + '=' + formattedValue;		
      }, undefined, context);

 => "person::fullName=Bediako George:shortName=Bediako:status=middle aged
     :birthDate=01-01-1970:age=43.0:friendList=[\"friend1\",\"friend2\",\"friend3\"]
     :familySet=[\"family1\"]:auditPostDate=:auditPutDate=:auditUserId=
     :id=6524d6f79d19"

sequence(Function f1, Function f2, … , Function fN)

Return type: Function

Returns a function that is the composition of the passed function arguments. The functions are executed in the order they are passed into sequence. Sequence's returned function can be used in a iterative manner on a resource or executed as a standalone. Sequence returns the value of the last function's execution. 

 var results = [];
 var sequence = resource.sequence(
      function() { results.push(1); },
      function() { results.push(2); },
      function() { results.push(3); },
      function() { results.push(4); }
 );
 sequence();

 => [1,2,3,4]

compose(Function f1, Function f2, …, Function fN)

Return type: Function

Returns a function that is the composition of the passed function arguments. The functions are executed in the order they are passed in to Compose. Compose's returned function can be used in a iterative manner on a resource or executed as a standalone. On execution, the function returned by Compose passes its arguments to the first function executed. Each function after that will get the return value of the previous function as a replacement for the first argument of the original arguments. Compose returns the value of the last function's execution. 

var results = [];

var compose = resource.compose(
    function() { results.push(1); },
    function() { results.push(2); },
    function() { results.push(3); },
    function() { results.push(4); }
);

compose();

=> [1,2,3,4]

toString(String resourceName, Object resource, Object context)

Return type: String

Returns a string representation of a resource. 

 var bediako = {fullName: 'Bediako George', shortName: 'Bediako'};
 resource.toString('person', bediako);

 => [** person
 	fullName: Bediako George
shortName: Bediako
    ]

watch(String attributeName1, …, String attributeNameN, Function watchFunction)

Return type: Function

Returns a function that will only be executed once and only once when the all the attributes in the argument list of nameList are visited by the iterative function. If an attribute list is not passed as arguments or as an array, watch will execute once and only once all the attributes of the iterative context are visited. 

 var executionTest = [], attributes = {};
 var watchFunction = function(_value, _attributeName, _resource, _metadata)
      {
           executionTest.push(1);
           attributes[_attributeName] = (attributes[_attributeName]
                && attributes[_attributeName] + 1)||1;
 };
 var watch = resource.watch('birthDate', 'age', watchFunction);
 resource.each('person', bediako, watch, undefined, context);
 var result = {age: 1};

 => attributes: {age: 1}

json(Object resource, Object replacer)

Return type: Function

Converts an object into a string by calling JSON.stringify(). 

 resource.json({});
 => '{}'
 
 resource.json(['bediako']);
 => '["bediako"]'
 
 resource.json({number: new Packages.java.lang.Integer(1)});
 => '{"number":1}'
 
 resource.json({time: new Date(5)});
 => '{"time":"1970-01-01T00:00:00.005Z"}'

audit(Object config)

Return type: n/A

Records audit information associated with an action on a particular resource. The 'config' object is a set of key/value pairs that configure the audit request. It includes an entity (com.google.appengine.api.datastore.Entity), an id (java.lang.String|String), an action (java.lang.String|String), and a resourceName (java.lang.String|String). 

 var in = require('airlift/incoming')
 var entity = in.createEntity('person', 'Bediako');
 entity.setProperty('fullName', 'Bediako George');
 entity.setProperty('shortName', 'Bediako');
 resource.audit({entity: entity, action: 'INSERT'});
 => undefined //records information to datastore

copy(Object target, Object value, String attributeName)

Return type: n/A

Copies each 'attributeName' of 'value' into 'target'. 

 var target = {};

 resource.each('person', bediako, resource.copy.partial(target), undefined, context);
 
 => {"fullName":"Bediako George","shortName":"Bediako","status":"middle aged",
     "birthDate":"1970-01-01T05:00:00.000Z","age":43,
     "friendList":["friend1","friend2","friend3"],"familySet":["family1"],
     "id":"6524d6f79d19"}

clone(Object value)

Return type: Object

Creates a new instance of 'value', copies all the attributes to the new instance and returns it. 

 var target = resource.map('person', bediako, resource.clone, undefined, context);

 => {"fullName":"Bediako George","shortName":"Bediako","status":"middle aged",
     "birthDate":"1970-01-01T05:00:00.000Z","age":43,
     "friendList":["friend1","friend2","friend3"],"familySet":["family1"],
     "id":"6524d6f79d19"}

stream(Function iterator, Function serialize, Function write, Array separators)

Return type: n/A

Streams content from the iterator using the provided serializer and writer until all the items in the iterator are processed. 

 var da = require('airlift/da/collect').create(_web);
 var persons = da.collect('person');
 var serialize = function(_person) {
      return JSON.stringify(_person);
 };
 var writer =
 {
      this.write = function(_content) {
           util.info(_content);
      };
      this.end = function() {
      };
 };
 resource.stream(persons, serialize, writer, '[',',',']');
 => undefined //writes data to stream

Collection

The Collection module contains functions that can be used to traverse and process JavaScript arrays and Java collections in the same manner.

The Collection module contains handy functions developers can use to traverse a JavaScript array, or a Java ArrayList or Java Set in a similar manner. Each function takes three parameters: collection, function, and context.

The collection parameter can be a java.util.Collection, a java.lang.String, a Javascript array, or a Javascript string to iterate over. The given function will be applied to every member of that collection or array, or every character of the java.lang.String or Javascript string. The function can expect the item/character, index, and collection/string to be passed to it at runtime. These functions can be used by including the following code:

 var collection = require('airlift/collection');

every(Object collection, Function iterator, Object context)

Return type: boolean

Returns true if all of the values in the list pass the iterator truth test. For JavaScript arrays, this function delegates to the native every function. The iteration stops once all the members of the collection have been visited or if the function ever returns false. 

 var users = ['Bediako', 'Dave', 'Loki'];
 var success = collection.every(users, function(_item, _index, _collection)
      {
           return true;
      })

 => true

forEach(Object collection, Function iterator, Object context)

Return type: n/A

Iterates over a collection of elements, yielding each in turn to an iterator function. The iterator is bound to the context object, if one is passed. Each invocation of iterator is called with three arguments: (item, index, collection). For JavaScript arrays this function delegates to the native forEach function. 

 var users = ["Bediako", "Dave", "Loki"];
 var index = 0;
 var results = [];

 collection.forEach(users, function(_item, _index, _collection)
      {
           results.push('Hello, ' + _item);
      });

 => ['Hello, Bediako', 'Hello, Dave', 'Hello, Loki']

filter(Object collection, Function iterator, Object context)

Return type: java.util.List|Array

Looks through each value in the list, returning a collection of all the values that pass a truth test (iterator). For JavaScript arrays this function delegates to the native filter method. 

 var array = [1, true, 20, 'hello'];
 var index = 0;
 var results = collection.filter(array, function(_item, _index, _collection)
      {
           if (_index % 2 === 0)
           {
                return false;
           }
           else
           {
                return true;
      }
 });

 => [true, 'hello']

map(Object collection, Function iterator, Object context)

Return type: java.util.List|Array

Produces a new collection of values by mapping each value in the collection through a transformation function (iterator). For JavaScript arrays, the native map method is used. Returns a new collection of values that contains every result returned by the execution of function against every item in the collection. 

 var users = ['Bediako', 'Dave', 'Loki'];
 var index = 0;
 var results = collection.map(users, function(_item, _index, _collection)
      {
           return _item + ' is the best!';
      });

 => ['Bediako is the best!', 'Dave is the best!', 'Loki is the best!']

some(Object collection, Function iterator, Object context)

Return type: boolean

Applies an iterator truth test to each item in the collection. The iteration will stop once all the members of the collection have been visited OR if the iterator function ever returns true. Returns true if the function returned true for any item it visited. 

 var array = [1, true, 20, 'hello'];
 var pass = collection.some(array, function(_item, _index, _collection)
     {
         return ("hello".equalsIgnoreCase(_item) === true);
     });
 _assert.eq(true, pass, 'failed');

 => true

split(Object collection, Function iterator, Object context)

Return type: Object

Returns an object with two array collections, success and fail. The first collection, success, contains the items for which \_function returned true. The second collection, fail, contains the items for which the function returned false. 

 var array = [1, true, 20, 'hello'];
 var index = 0;
 var result = collection.split(array, function(_item, _index, _collection)
      {
           if (_index % 2 === 0)
           {
                return false;
           }
           else
           {
	    return true;
           }
});

 => result.success: [true, 'hello']
 => result.fail: [1, 20]

partition(Object collection, String attributeName)

Return type: Object

Returns an object containing a value list (java.util.List or Javascript array) and a map (java.util.Map or Javascript object). The value list is stored in property 'keys' and contains, in the order they were discovered, the set of values that each item in the collection had on its property, attribute. The map is stored in property 'partition.' The map's keys are the values found in the value list. Each key points to the list of items that had that value on its property identified by attributeName. 

 var array = [];	
 array.push({name: 'Bediako'});
 array.push({name: 'Loki'});
 array.push({name: 'Connor'});
 array.push({name: 'Bediako'});

 var partition = collection.partition(array, 'name');

 => ['Bediako', 'Loki', 'Connor']

reduce(Object collection, Function iterator, Object initialValue, Object context)

Return type: Object

Reduce boils down a collection of values into a single value. 'initialValue' is the initial state of the reduction, and each successive step of it should be returned by iterator. Reduce defers to the native implementation for JavaScript arrays. 

 var array = [1, true, 20, 'hello'];
 var result = collection.reduce(array, function(_result, _item, _index, _collection)
     {
         return _result + '' + _item;
     }, '');

 => '1true20hello'

 var set = new java.util.HashSet();
 set.add(1);
 set.add(2);
 set.add(3);
 set.add(4);
 var result = collection.reduce(set, function(_result, _item, _index, _collection)
     {
         return _result + _item.intValue();
     }, 0);

 => 10

Rest

The Rest module contains functions that allow for simple information requests to restful servers.

The RESTful server, an architectural style of coding, allows Airlift a number of advantages. By only using HTTP requests such as GET, COLLECT, PUT, POST, and DELETE in the client-server relationship, REST allows for any client capable of understanding HTTP to easily request information from a RESTful server. In addition, the firm separation of the client and the server allow for one or the other to be replaced or developed independently of the other. This also enables more easily scalable server capacity.

Airlift’s implementation of RESTful functions may be used when writing HTML request handlers, and are described below. For further reference, please consult the source code.

collect(Object config)

Return type: java.util.Iterator

Creates a java.util.Collection of all the resources(?) and returns an iterator over the collection. 

 var collect = require('airlift/da/collect')
 'Example code coming soon.'

collectBy(String attributeName, Object value, Object config)

Return type: java.util.Iterator

Returns an iterator over a filtered collection of resources that have attribute name 'attributeName'. 

 'Example code coming soon.'

collectByMembership(String resourceName, String attributeName, java.lang.Iterable membershipList, Object config)

Return type: java.util.Iterator

Description under construction. 

 'Example code coming soon.'

delete(Object config)

Return type: n/A

Retrieves the id from 'config' and deletes the resource. 

 'Example code coming soon.'

get(Object config)

Return type: Object

Retrives the resources name and id from 'config'. 

 'Example code coming soon.'

getAll(Object config)

Return type: Object

Description under construction. 

 'Example code coming soon.'

post(Object config)

Return type: Object

Generates a resourceName, id, and entity for the resource. 

 'Example code coming soon.'

put(Object config)

Return type: Object

Updates an existing resource. 

 'Example code coming soon.'

Util

The Util module contains utility functions that are used throughout Airlift.

The Util module contains utility functions developers can use process resources. These include checks for empty JavaScript objects, type checks, multi trys and more. Use these functions by including the following code:

 var util = require('airlift/util')

typeOf(Object value)

Return type: String

Determines the type of JavaScript object value. 

 util.typeOf({});                        => "object"
 util.typeOf(function() {});             => "function"
 util.typeOf([]);                        => "array"
 util.typeOf(1);                         => "number"
 util.typeOf('1');                       => "string"
 util.typeOf(new java.lang.Object());    => "object"
 util.typeOf(new java.lang.String());    => "object"

isEmpty(Object o)

Return type: boolean

Determines whether or not a JavaScript object has any properties. 

 util.isEmpty({});                       => true
 util.isEmpty({name: 'Serena'});         => false

createClass(String className)

Return type: Object

Creates a Java class object identified by the classname. 

 util.createClass('java.lang.String');                  
 => class java.lang.String

 util.createClass('airlift.util.JavaScriptingUtil');
 => class airlift.util.JavaScriptingUtil

isWhitespace(String string)

Return type: boolean

Returns true if string is whitespace, false otherwise. 

 util.isWhitespace('');                  => true
 util.isWhitespace('    \t\n');          => true
 util.isWhitespace('    \t\nxyz  \t');   => false

hasValue(Object value)

Return type: boolean

Returns true if item is not equal to null and is not equal to undefined. 

 util.hasValue('');                      => true
 util.hasValue([])                       => true
 util.hasValue({})                       => true
 util.hasValue(-1)                       => true
 util.hasValue(true)                     => true
 util.hasValue(null);                    => false
 util.hasValue(undefined);               => false

createErrorReporter()

Return type: Object

Creates an object that handles error reporting. This object includes methods allErrors(), getErrors(String name), hasErrors(), report(String name, String error), and clear(). 

 var errorReporter = util.createErrorReporter();
 errorReporter.report('hello', 'message1', 'test');
 errorReporter.report('hello', 'message2', 'test');
 errorReporter.report('goodbye', 'message3', 'test');
 var result = errorReporter.allErrors();

 => {hello:[{name: 'hello', message: 'message1', category: 'test'},
      {name: 'hello', message: 'message2', category: 'test'}],
      goodbye: [{name: 'goodbye', message: 'message3', category: 'test'}]}

multiTry(Function executable, Number tryCount, Function completeFailure)

Return type: Object

Tries to execute function 'tryCount' number of times, catching any exceptions encountered. If 'executable' is successfully executed, it's value is stored in result. If the number of failed tries exceeds try a severe error is logged, and the last exception encountered is rethrown unless callback function is provided. 

 var list = util.list();
 util.multiTry(function() { list.add('star'); }, 5);
 => ["star"]

 list = util.list();
 util.multiTry(function(_tries) 
      { list.add('star'); if (_tries < 3) throw 'error'; }, 3);
 => ["star","star","star"]

 list = util.list();
 util.multiTry(function(_tries) 
                { list.add('try'); if (_tries < 4) throw 'error'; }, 3,
                function(_tries, _exception)
                { list.add('completely failed'); });
 => ["try","try","try","completely failed"]

createDate(Number milliseconds)

Return type: java.util.Date

If milliseconds is provided it is passed to the Date constructor, otherwise the date returned will reflect the current time to the millisecond. 

 var date = util.createDate();           => Fri Jul 05 12:22:26 EDT 2013
 var date = util.createDate(0);          => Wed Dec 31 19:00:00 EST 1969

createTimezone(String id)

Return type: java.util.TimeZone

Creates a timezone of location 'id', which can either be an abbreviation such as "EST", a full name such as "America/New_York", or a custom ID such as "GMT+9:00". 

 var timezone = util.timezone('America/New_York');
 => sun.util.calendar.ZoneInfo[id="America/New_York",offset=-18000000,
    dstSavings=3600000,useDaylight=true,transitions=235,
    lastRule=java.util.SimpleTimeZone[id=America/New_York,offset=-18000000,
    dstSavings=3600000,useDaylight=true,startYear=0,startMode=3,startMonth=2,
    startDay=8,startDayOfWeek=1,startTime=7200000,startTimeMode=0,endMode=3,
    endMonth=10,endDay=1,endDayOfWeek=1,endTime=7200000,endTimeMode=0]]

formatDate(java.util.Date|Date utcDate, String format, String timezone)

Return type: String

Formats a java.util.Date or Javascript Date into an easily readable string. 

 var date = new Date(1375110037982);
 var formattedDate = util.formatDate(date, 'MMMM dd, yyyy');
 => "July 29, 2013"

 var formattedDate = util.formatDate(date, 'EEE, dd MMM yyyy hh:mm:ss zzz');
 => "Mon, 29 Jul 2013 11:00:37 EDT"

adjustUTCDate(java.util.Date|Date utcDate, java.util.Timezone|Timezone timezone)

Return type: java.util.Date

Returns an adjusted date that is the addition of the current UTC date and specified timezone. 

 var date = util.date();
 var adjustedDate = util.adjustUTCDate(date, 'America/New_York');
 => Fri Jul 05 09:23:12 EDT 2013

 var timezone = util.timezone('America/New_York');
 var offset = timezone.getOffset(date.getTime());
 var newDate = util.date(date.getTime() + offset);
 => Fri Jul 05 09:23:12 EDT 2013

createCalendar(Object config)

Return type: java.util.Calendar

Creates a java.util.Calendar object. The optional config parameter may contain the following optional parameters:

  • date - a date the calendar will be set to. If not provided the current date is used.
  • dateOffset - the amount of time to adjust the calendar from the date it was set to. Defaults to 0.
  • dateOffsetType - the dateOffset time amount from the java.util.Calendar object. Defaults to java.util.Calendar.MILLISECOND.
  • timezone - the timezone the calendar object should be set to. Defaults to ‘UTC’.
  • locale - the locale the calendar object should be set to. Defaults to current locale.

The config object may have all or none of these parameters.

 var date = new Packages.java.util.Date();
 var calendar = util.createCalendar({date: date});
 => java.util.GregorianCalendar[time=1373046196220,areFieldsSet=false,
     areAllFieldsSet=false,lenient=true,zone=sun.util.calendar.ZoneInfo
     [id="UTC",offset=0,dstSavings=0,useDaylight=false,transitions=0,
     lastRule=null],firstDayOfWeek=1,minimalDaysInFirstWeek=1,ERA=1,
     YEAR=2013,MONTH=6,WEEK_OF_YEAR=27,WEEK_OF_MONTH=1,DAY_OF_MONTH=5,
     DAY_OF_YEAR=186,DAY_OF_WEEK=6,DAY_OF_WEEK_IN_MONTH=1,AM_PM=1,HOUR=5,
     HOUR_OF_DAY=17,MINUTE=43,SECOND=16,MILLISECOND=220,ZONE_OFFSET=0,
     DST_OFFSET=0]

guid(Number length)

Return type: String

Creates a guid of type string. The method for creating the guid involves truncating a SHA1 hash of a random uuid created by java.util.GUID class. The SHA1 hash is truncated to the length specified. If length is not specified the value of the application configuration parameter 'airlift.truncated.sha1.id.length' is used instead. If that is not configured it defaults to 32. 

 var id = util.guid(12);                 => c30215c36032
 var id = util.guid();                   => 741ca9295cf204886893257202e8559b

trim(String string)

Return type: String

Removes whitespace from left and right sides of a string. 

 var trimmed = util.trim('\t Josh \n')
 => 'Josh'

print()

Return type: n/A

Writes string to standard out. 

 util.print('purple');
 STDOUT: purple

println()

Return type: n/A

Writes string to standard out, then writes a newline to standard out. 

util.println('pandas');
STDOUT: pandas

info()

Return type: n/A

Concatenates arguments and prints it to the command line. 'INFO: ' preceeds the message. 

 util.info('hello','world');
 STDOUT: INFO: hello world

warning()

Return type: n/A

Concatenates arguments and prints it to the command line. 'WARNING: ' preceeds the message. 

 util.warning('proceed with caution');
 STDOUT: WARNING: proceed with caution

info()

Return type: n/A

Concatenates arguments and prints it to the command line. 'SEVERE: ' preceeds the message. 

 util.severe('Something has gone terribly wrong.');
 STDOUT: SEVERE: Something has gone terribly wrong.

value(Object candidate, Object default)

Return type: Object

Returns 'candidate' if it is not null or it is not undefined. Otherwise it returns 'default'. 

 var result = util.value(['a','b','c'], ['default']);   => ['a','b','c']
 var result = util.value(undefined, 0);                 => 0
 var result = util.value('Serena', undefined);          => 'Serena'
 var result = util.value(undefined, null);              => null

primitive(Object o)

Return type: Object

Converts primitive Java values into primitive Javascript values. If 'o' is not a primitive Java value, returns it unchanged. 

 var integer = new Packages.java.lang.Integer(1);
 var jsNumber = 1;

 _assert.eq(util.primitive(integer), jsNumber, 'one integer is incorrect');
 // OK ...

callbackIterator(Function iterator, Function callback)

Return type: Java.util.Iterator

Generates an iterator that executes the callback function each time next() is called. 

 var list = util.list();
 list.add('twinkling');
 list.add('shining');
 list.add('bright');

 var starryList = util.list();

 var iterator = list.iterator();
 var callbackIterator = util.callbackIterator(iterator,
      function(_next) { starryList.add(_next+' star'); });

 for (var item in Iterator(callbackIterator)) { } //exercises the iterator

 //=> ['twinkling star', 'shining star', 'bright star']

list(Object parameter)

Return type: java.util.ArrayList

If no parameter is given, returns a new empty java.util.ArrayList. Otherwise, passes 'parameter' to the java.util.ArrayList constructor method. 

 var list = util.list();
 list.add('element1');
 list.add('element2');
 list.add('element3');

 var copy = util.list(list);
 => ['element1', 'element2', 'element3']

set(Object parameter)

Return type: java.util.HashSet

If no parameter is given, returns a new empty java.util.HashSet. Otherwise, passes 'parameter' to the java.util.HashSet constructor method. 

 var set = util.set();
 set.add('element1');
 set.add('element2');
 set.add('element3');

 var copy = util.set(set);
 => ['element1', 'element2', 'element3']

orderedSet(Object parameter)

Return type: java.util.TreeSet

If no parameter is given, returns a new empty java.util.TreeSet. Otherwise, passes 'parameter' to the java.util.TreeSet constructor method. 

 var orderedSet = util.orderedSet();
 orderedSet.add('element3');
 orderedSet.add('element1');
 orderedSet.add('element2');

 var copy = util.orderedSet(orderedSet);
 => ['element1', 'element2', 'element']

map(Object parameter)

Return type: java.util.HashMap

If no parameter is given, returns a new empty java.util.HashMap. Otherwise, passes 'parameter' to the java.util.HashMap constructor method. 

 var map = util.map();
 map.put('element', 1);

 var copy = util.map(map);
 => {element=1.0}

createKeysIterator(Collection entityList)

Return type: java.util.Iterator

Returns an iterator that iterates through the keys of 'entitylist' given a collection of entities. 

var in = require('airlift/incoming');

var list = util.list();
list.add(in.createEntity('person', 9817);
list.add(in.createEntity('person', 9818);
list.add(in.createEntity('person', 9819);

var iterator = util.createKeysIterator(list);
iterator.next();               => 9817
iterator.next();               => 9818
iterator.next();               => 9819

createKeysCollection(Collection entityList)

Return type: java.util.Collection

Returns a collection of the keys of an entity collection. 

var in = require('airlift/incoming');

var list = util.list();
list.add(in.createEntity('person', 9817);
list.add(in.createEntity('person', 9818);
list.add(in.createEntity('person', 9819);

var collection = util.createKeysCollection(list);
var set = util.set(collection);

set.toString();
=> [9817, 9818, 9819]

createKeysIterable(Collection entityList)

Return type: java.lang.Iterable

Creates an iterable of 'entitylist'. This iterable has a method iterator(), which calls createKeysIterator(). 

var list = util.list();
list.add({getKey: function() { return 'ichi'; }});
list.add({getKey: function() { return 'ni'; }});
list.add({getKey: function() { return 'san'; }});

var iterable = util.createKeysIterable(list);
var iterator = iterable.iterator();
iterator.next();               => 9817
iterator.next();               => 9818
iterator.next();               => 9819

getResourceMetadata(String resourceName)

Return type: Object

Retrieves the resource metadata of 'resourceName' by requiring 'meta/r/' + 'resourceName'. The returned object holds metadata information as its properties. This metadata is generated by Airlift. 

 var r = util.getResourceMetadata('person');
 => {
    "isView":false,
    "isPresented":true,
    "isPersisted":true,
    "isCached":true,
    "isSecured":true,
    "isAudited":false,
    "name":"person",
    "attributes":["firstName", "familyName", "nickName", "birthDate",
                  "auditPostDate", "auditPutDate", "auditUserId",
                  "auditRequestId", "id"],
    "foreignKeys":{},
    "indexedProperties":{"familyName":1, "birthDate":1, "auditPostDate":1,
                         "auditPutDate":1, "auditUserId":1,
                         "auditRequestId":1},
    "searchProperties":{"auditPostDate":1, "auditPutDate":1,
                        "auditUserId":1, "auditRequestId":1},
    "encryptedProperties":{}
    }

getAttributesMetadata(String resourceName)

Return type: Object

Retrieves the attribute metadata of 'resourceName' by requiring 'meta/a/' + 'resourceName'. The returned object holds metadata information as its properties. This metadata is generated by Airlift. 

 var a = util.getAttributeMetadata('person');
 //this is an abbreviated example output
 => {
    "resourceName":"person",
    "attributes":
        {
        "firstName":

            "name":"firstName",

            "isSearchable":false,
            "isIndexable":false,
            },
        "familyName":
            {"name":"familyName",
            "type":"java.lang.String",
            "isSearchable":false,
            "isIndexable":true}
        }
    }

getWebRequestId()

Return type: java.util.String

 var id = util.getWebRequestId();
 => 32hbi3k700qq03948273849a4b0100327f7f74242272000981700100

string(String string)

Return type: java.lang.String

 var string = new String('Hello');

 var number = 5;

leftPad(java.lang.String|String item, Number num, String padding)

Return type: java.lang.String|String

Adds padding to the left side so that the number of digits is equal to 'num'. 

 var string = '9';
 util.leftPad(string, 5, '0');
 => '00009'

rightPad(java.lang.String|String item, Number num, String padding)

Return type: java.lang.String|String

Adds padding to the right side so that the number of digits is equal to 'num'. 

 var string = new Packages.java.lang.String('9);
 util.rightPad(string, 5, '0');
 => '90000'

hash(Function algorithm, String message, Number length)

Return type: String

Uses a hash generation 'algorithm' to create a hash from the 'message'. If 'length' is provided, the hash will be of length 'length'. 

var hash12 = util.hash('SHA1', 'Pandas are the best', 12);
=> '89678d4ac57e'
var hash24 = util.hash('SHA1', 'Pandas are the best', 24);
=> '2493adb482d389678d4ac57e'

load(String resourcePath)

Return type: String

Given the pathway to a resource, finds returns the resource as a string. 

 var assertResourceString = util.load('airlift/assert.js');
 assertResourceString.substring(0, 14);
 => "// http://wiki"

Given the pathway to a resource, finds returns the resource as a string. 

 var stringBuffer = util.stringBuffer('Hello');
 stringBuffer.getClass();

 stringBuffer.toString();
 => "Hello"

appProfile()

Return type: Packages.airlift.app.appProfile

Creates a new object of the class appProfile that is generated by Dictation. This class contains security info, and additional information. 

 var appProfile = util.appProfile();
 => //an appProfile class

sanitize(Object resource)

Return type: Object

Removes bookkeeping metadata from 'resource'. Removed properties include auditUserId, auditRequestId, auditPostDate, and auditPutDate. 

var resource =
    {
        name: 'ex bookkeeping metadata',
        auditUserId: '1a2b3c4d',
        auditRequestId: '5e6f7g8h',
        auditPostDate: new Date(1375110037982),
        auditPostDate: new Date(1375110051100),
    };
var sanitizedResource = util.sanitize(resource);
=> {name: 'ex bookkeeping metadata'}

printStackTraceToString(java.lang.Throwable throwable)

Return type: String

When an error occurs, logs and prints the stack to simplify debugging. 

 try
 {
      throw new Packages.java.lang.RuntimeException();
 }
 catch (e)
 {
      var stackTrace = util.printStackTraceToString(e);
      util.print(stackTrace);
 }
 => java.lang.RuntimeException
 => 	at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance0
    (Native Method)

getJavaException(java.lang.Exception|Object exception)

Return type: java.lang.Exception

Captures an exception and returns it. 

 try
 {
      throw new Packages.java.lang.RuntimeException();
 }
 catch (e)
 {
      var exception = util.getJavaException(e);
      util.print(exception.getClass());
 }
 => "java.lang.RuntimeException"

 try
 {
      var error = {message: 'error', javaException: 
          new Packages.java.lang.RuntimeException()};
      throw error;
 }
 catch (e)
 {
      var exception = util.getJavaException(e);
      util.print(exception.getClass());
 }
 => "java.lang.RuntimeException"

now()

Return type: java.lang.Long

Returns the current time in milliseconds. 

 var now = util.now();
 => 1373315350625

Incoming

The Incoming module contains functions that are generally used when processing incoming data such as during a post, put, or a delete.

The Incoming module contains functions for processing incoming data. This includes data conversion and validation; data encryption, audit and persistence. To use these functions, include the following line of code:

 var in = require('airlift/incoming');

createKey(String resourceName, String guid)

Return type: com.google.appengine.api.datastore.Key

Uses Google appengine's KeyFactory to creates a new Key having no parent from its kind and ID. 

 var util = require('airlift/util');
 var key = in.createKey('person', util.guid(12));

 key.getKind();      => 'person'
 key.getName();      => '6b466a1c7142'
 key.getClass();     => 'com.google.appengine.api.datastore.Key'

createEntity(String resourceName, String guid)

Return type: com.google.appengine.api.datastore.Entity

Uses Google appengine to create a new Entity uniquely identified by the provided Key. 

 var util = require('airlift/util');
 var entity = in.createEntity('person', util.guid(12));
 entity.getKind();
 => 'person'

bookkeeping(Entity entity, String userid, Date postDate, Date putDate)

Return type: n/A

Populates the entity object with the bookkeeping metadata that describes when this object was created and by whom it was created. If userId is not provided and cannot be determined systematically 'user id not provided' is recorded. If postDate is not provided the current date and time is used instead. If putDate is not provided the postDate is used instead. 

 var util = require('airlift/util');
 var person = in.createEntity('person', util.guid(12));
 in.bookkeeping(person, 'bediako', util.createDate());
 person.getProperty("auditUserId");
 => 'bediako'

entify(Entity entity, Object value, String attributeName, Object resource, Object attributeMetadata)

Return type: n/A

Converts 'resource' attribute values into a property map values on an 'entity'. Designed to be used with resource.each. 

 var util = require('airlift/util');
 var resource = require('airlift/resource');

 var person = {};
 person.id = util.guid(12);
 person.fullName = "Kwame Mtume"
 person.age = 27;

 var entity = in.createEntity('person', person.id);
 resource.each('person', person, in.entify.partial(entity));
 //'entity' is now populated with attributes from 'person'

encrypt(Entity entity, Object value, String attributeName, Object resource, Object attributeMetadata)

Return type: n/A

Converts 'resource's sensitive attribute values into encrypted property map values on an entity object. Designed to be used with resource.each. 

 var resource = require('airlift/resource');

 var person = {};
 person.id = '007';
 person.fullName = 'Josh Lee'
 person.secretInfo = '555-55-5555';

 var entity = in.createEntity('person', person.id);
 resource.each('person', person, in.encrypt.partial(entity));
 //secret info is encrypted and stored in 'entity' along with other
     // 'person' attributes

convert(Object value, String attributeName, Object resource, Object attributeMetadata)

Return type: n/A

Converts a request parameter values into a property map values on a JavaScript object. Designed to be used with resource.each. It relies on Airlift automatically setting the web context object that resource.each relies on. 

 // imcoming PUT to URI: http://www.example.com/a/person/asdf?
     // fullName=Kwame%20Mtume&secretInfo=555-55-5555&age=27

 var resource = require('airlift/resource');

 var person = {};

 resource.each('person', person, in.encrypt.partial(entity));
 // person now has {'id': 'asdf', 'fullName': 'Kwame Mtume',
     // 'secretInfo': '55-55-5555', 'age': 27}

validate(Object value, String name, Object resource, Object metadata)

Return type: Object

Function designed to be used with resource.each, it verifies that the resource's property values are in line with the constraints outlined in the attribute and resource metadata. Use resource.watch to get hold of the errors at the end of the validation. 

 var util = require('airlift/util');
 var resource = require('airlift/resource');
 var bediako = {};

 bediako.id = '6524d6f79d19';
 bediako.fullName = new Packages.java.lang.String('Bediako George');
 bediako.shortName = new Packages.java.lang.String('Bediako');
 bediako.status = null; //an error should be reported on this property
 bediako.birthDate = new Packages.java.util.Date(new Date('01/01/1970')
      .getTime());
 bediako.age = new Packages.java.lang.Integer(43).intValue();
 bediako.friendList = new Packages.java.util.ArrayList();
 bediako.familySet = new Packages.java.util.HashSet();

 var errors;
 var bediakoCopy = resource.map('person', bediako, resource.clone,
      undefined, context);

 resource.each('person', bediakoCopy, resource.sequence(in.validate,
      resource.watch(function() { errors = this.allErrors(); })),
      undefined, context);

 util.isEmpty(errors);
 => false
 errors.status.length;
 => 1

Outgoing

The Outgoing module contains functions used in the retrieval of data. Typically this is used when getting or collecting data from the datastore.

The Outgoing module contains functions for processing retrieved data. This includes functions for unencrypting data, and converting entities into JavaScript objects.

 var out = require('airlift/outgoing')

deentify(Entity entity, Object value, String attributeName, Object resource, Object attributeMetadata)

Return type: Object

Converts an entity's property values into a JavaScript's objects attribute values. Returns 'value' as a Javascript object. Designed to be used with resource.each. 

 var util = require('airlift/util');
 var in = require('airlift/incoming');
 var resource = require('airlift/resource');

 var person = {};
 var entity = in.createEntity('person', util.guid(12));
 entity.setProperty('fullName', 'Josh Lee');
 entity.setProperty('age', 24);

 resource.each('person', person, out.deentify.partial(entity));
 => {'fullName': 'Josh Lee', 'age': 24}

decrypt(Entity entity, Object value, String attributeName, Object resource, Object attributeMetadata)

Return type: Object

Deciphers the encrypted value associated with 'attributeName' and sets the property map values on to 'entity'. Returns the decrypted value. Designed to be used with resource.each. 

 var in = require('airlift/incoming');
 var resource = require('airlift/resource');

 var person = {};
 var entity = in.createEntity('person', '007');
 entity.setProperty('fullName', 'Josh Lee');
 entity.setProperty('secretInfo', 'encrypted_secret_info_28s9l9e9ba2');

 resource.each('person', person, out.decrypt.partial(entity));
 => {'id': '007', 'fullName': 'Josh Lee', 'secretInfo': '555-55-5555'}
 //secret info is decrypted and stored in 'entity' along with other
      'person' attributes

JavaArray

The JavaArray module provides functions for creating Java arrays of various generics.

The following functions will initialize a Java array, copying over Javascript array elements if given.

 var javaArray = require('airlift/javaArray');

createArray(Number size, Class type, Array initializer)

Return type: java.lang.Object

Creates a Java array of the specified size and type. If an initialization array is provided, the contents of that array are copied to the Java array. 'size' is the initial size of the array and defaults to 0. 'type' is the Java type of the array and defults to java.lang.String. 'initializer' is an array of values that should be copied to the array and defaults to an empty array. 

 var stringArray = javaArray.createArray(3, java.lang.String, ["Bediako", "Loki"]);
 java.util.Arrays.toString(stringArray);
 => '[Bediako, Loki, null]'

 stringArray.getClass();
 => [Ljava.lang.String;

The following functions also serve to initialize Java arrays. Each function requires two parameters, Number size and Array initializer. The functions call this module’s createArray function, passing the two parameters as well as the appropriate Class type.



Function(Number size, Array initializer) Description
stringArray Returns a Java string array.
byteArray Returns a Java byte array.
byteObjectArray Returns a Java byte object array.
shortArray Returns a Java short array.
shortObjectArray Returns a Java short object array.
charArray Returns a Java char array.
characterObjectArray Returns a Java character object array.
intArray Returns a Java int array.
integerObjectArray Returns a Java integer array.
longArray Returns a Java long array.
longObjectArray Returns a Java long object array.
booleanArray Returns a Java boolean array.
booleanObjectArray Returns a Java boolean object array.
floatArray Returns a Java float array.
floatObjectArray Returns a Java float object array.
doubleArray Returns a Java double array.
doubleObjectArray Returns a Java double object array. 

 var array = javaArray.intArray(5, [1, 2, 3]);
 => [1, 2, 3, 0, 0]
 array.getClass();
 => [I
 array.length;
 => 5

Service

The Service module includes functions that a service can use to get queues, application ids, and caches.

Airlift’s service functions are designed to be compatible with Google AppEngine. The module consists of three functions: getQueueService(), getAppIdentityService, and getCacheService. A call to these functions will initialize a Javascript Object that mimicks Google AppEngine’s Queue, AppIdentityService, and MemcacheService interfaces, respectively. The Javascript object includes functional properties that call the interface’s methods.

 var service = require('airlift/service');

getQueueService(java.lang.String|String name, java.lang.String|String method).name

Return type: java.lang.String|String

Creates a com.google.appengine.api.taskqueue Queue object and returns 'name'. 

 service.getQueueService("serviceName", "POST").name;
 => "serviceName"

getQueueService(java.lang.String|String name, java.lang.String|String method).method

Return type: java.lang.String|String

Creates a com.google.appengine.api.taskqueue Queue object and returns 'method'. If method is undefined, defaults to 'POST'. 

service.getQueueService("serviceName", "GET").method;
=> "GET"

getQueueService(java.lang.String|String name, java.lang.String|String method).add(java.lang.String|String path, Object parameters)

Return type: n/A

Submits a task to the queue. Creates a com.google.appengine.api.taskqueue Queue object. Uses 'method' to initializes a com.google.appengine.api.taskqueue.TaskOptions and sets the URL to null unless specified by 'path'. 'parameters' should be an Object with enumerable properties of type java.lang.String|String. Adds each named parameter into the TaskOptions Object and then passes it to Google AppEngine's Queue add() function. 

 var queuey = service.getQueueService("serviceName", "POST");
 var parameters = {};
 parameters['task1'] = "value1";
 parameters['task2'] = "value2";
 queuey.add("/url_pathway", parameters);

getQueueService(java.lang.String|String name, java.lang.String|String method).service()

Return type: com.google.appengine.api.taskqueue

Returns Packages.com.google.appengine.api.taskqueue.QueueFactory.getQueue(name) 

 var queue = service.getQueueService("serviceName", "POST").service();

getAppIdentityService().getAppId()

Return type: java.lang.String

Uses com.google.appengine.api.utils.SystemProperty to return the application identifier for the current application. 

 var appId = service.getAppIdentityService().getAppId();
 => 'com.example.myCoolApplication'

getAppIdentityService().getDomain()

Return type: java.lang.String

Uses com.google.appengine.api.appidentity.AppIdentityService.ParsedAppId to return the application's domain or the empty string if no domain. 

 var domainName = service.getAppIdentityService().getDomain();
 => 'example.com'

getAppIdentityService().getPartition()

Return type: java.lang.String

Uses com.google.appengine.api.appidentity.AppIdentityService.ParsedAppId to return the partition the application runs in. 

 var partition = service.getAppIdentityService().getPartition();
 => 'example.thisPartition.com'

getAppIdentityService().service()

Return type: com.google.appengine.api.appidentity.AppIdentityService

Returns com.google.appengine.api.appidentity.AppIdentityServiceFactory.getAppIdentityService(); 

 var appIdService = service.getAppIdentityService().service();
 // returns Google App Engine's AppIdentityService class

getCacheService().get(java.lang.Object key)

Return type: java.lang.Object

Uses com.google.appengine.api.memcache.MemcacheService to fetche a previously-stored value, or null if unset. 

 var value = service.getCacheService().get('key1');
 => 'key2'

getCacheService().getAll(java.util.Collection<T> keys)

Return type: <T> java.util.Map<T,java.lang.Object>

Uses com.google.appengine.api.memcache.MemcacheService to perform a get of multiple keys at once. 

 var keyList = new java.util.ArrayList();
 keyList.add('key1');
 keyList.add('key2');
 var values = service.getCacheService().getAll(keyList);
 => {"key1"="value1", "key2"="value2"}

getCacheService().put(java.lang.Object key, java.lang.Object value)

Return type: void

Uses com.google.appengine.api.memcache.MemcacheService to store a new value into the cache, using key, but subject to the policy regarding existing entries. 

 var key = 'key';
 var value = 'value';
 service.getCacheService().put(key, value);

getCacheService().putAll(java.util.Map<?,?> values)

Return type: void

Uses com.google.appengine.api.memcache.MemcacheService to store new values into the cache, using key, but subject to the policy regarding existing entries. 

 var map = new java.util.HashMap();
 map.put('key1', 'value1');
 map.put('key2', 'value2');
 service.getCacheService().putAll(map);

getCacheService().delete(java.lang.Object key)

Return type: boolean

Uses com.google.appengine.api.memcache.MemcacheService to remove key from the cache. 

 var key = 'key'
 service.getCacheService().delete(key);
 => true

getCacheService().service()

Return type: com.google.appengine.api.memcache.MemcacheService

Uses com.google.appengine.api.memcache.MemcacheServiceFactory to gets a handle to the cache service. 

 var memcache = service.getCacheService().service();

Web

The Web module provides mainly getter and setter functions for a web context's properties.

Web functions make available the various properties of a web context, which is passed into the module when executing the following code:

 var webContext = require('airlift/web');

getCachingContext Description
getTimezone Description
getResourceBindings Description
getWebRequestId Description


Setter functions:


Function() Description
setCacheable(Number seconds) Sets the browser to cache the page for 'seconds' seconds. By default, the cache is set to 86400 seconds or 24 hours.
setContent(Object content) Sets the content of the page to 'content'.
setResponseCode(Object code) Sets the response code web context to 'code'.
setType(String type) Sets the type of the web context to 'type'.

Assert

The assert module provides functions that throw AssertionErrors when particular conditions are not met.

Assert functions evaluate predicates and can help developers locate problems in their code, aiding the debugging process. All assertion methods provide both the actual and expected values to the assertion error for display purposes. Airlift’s many unit tests make extensive use of this module. The assert module can be found on CommonJS.

 var assert = require('airlift/assert');

fail(Object actual, Object expected, String message, String operator, String stackStartFunction)

Return type: n/A

Throws an AssertionError if the test case fails. 

 assert.fail(true, false, 'false positive', '===', assert.eq);
 THROWS: assert.AssertionError;

ok(Object value, String message)

Return type: n/A

Tests whether 'value' is truthy. 

 exports['test example'] = function(asserts)
 {
      assert.ok(1, 'result is not truthy');
 }

 STDOUT: OK ... test example

 exports['test example'] = function(asserts)
 {
      assert.ok(0, 'result is not truthy');
 }

 STDOUT:      result is not truthy true == 0
         Failed ... test example

eq(Object actual, Object expected, String message)

Return type: n/A

Tests for strict equality with ===. 

 exports['test example'] = function(asserts)
 {
      var result = 1;
      assert.eq(result, 'one', 'function failed to convert integer
           to written numbers');
 }

 STDOUT: OK ... test example

 exports['test example'] = function(asserts)
 {
      var result = 1;
      assert.eq(result, 'one', 'integer not converted to written numbers');
 }

 STDOUT:      integer not converted to written numbers ! == 1
         Failed ... test asserts

notEq(Object actual, Object expected, String message)

Return type: n/A

Tests for whether two objects are not equal with !== . 

 exports['test example'] = function(asserts)
 {
      var result = 2 + 2;
      assert.eq(result, 5, 'oh no, we've lapsed into an Orwellian society');
 }

 STDOUT OK ... test example

deepEqual(Object actual, Object expected, String message)

Return type: n/A

Tests a deep equality relation. 

 exports['test example'] = function(asserts)
 {
      var a = [1, 2, 3];
      var b = [1, 2, 3];
      assert.deepEqual(b, a, 'elements of two matrices were not equal.');
 }

 STDOUT OK ... test example

notDeepEqual(Object actual, Object expected, String message)

Return type: n/A

Tests for any deep inequality. 

 exports['test example'] = function(asserts)
 {
      var a = [1, 2, 3];
      var b = [1, 2, 4];
      assert.notDeepEqual(b, a, 'differing elements of two matrices were equal.');
 }

 STDOUT OK ... test example

kindaEqual(Object actual, Object expected, String message)

Return type: n/A

Tests equality, as determined by ==. 

 exports['test example'] = function(asserts)
 {
      var result = 1;
      assert.kindaEqual(result, 'one', 'result is incorrect');
 }

 STDOUT: OK ... test example

notKindaEqual(Object actual, Object expected, String message)

Return type: n/A

Tests for inequality, as determined by != . 

 exports['test example'] = function(asserts)
 {
      var result = 'luma';
      assert.notKindaEqual(result, null, 'error: needs more starbits');
 }

 STDOUT: OK ... test example

throws(Object block, Object error, String message)

Return type: n/A

Tests that 'block' throws an error as expected. 'error' and 'message' are optional. 'error' can be constructor, regexp or validation function. 

 exports['test example'] = function(asserts)
 {
      list = util.list();
      assert.throws(function()
           {
                util.multiTry(function(_tries, _exception)
                     {
                          list.add('stuff');
                          if (_tries < 6) throw 'error';
                      }, 5);
           },'multi try should throw an exception');
 }

 STDOUT OK ... test example

doesNotThrow(Object block, Object error, String message)

Return type: n/A

Tests that 'block' does not throw an error. 'error' and 'message' are optional. 'error' can be constructor, regexp or validation function. 

 exports['test example'] = function(asserts)
 {
      list = util.list();
      assert.doesNotThrows(function()
           {
                util.multiTry(function(_tries, _exception)
                     {
                          list.add('stuff');
                          if (_tries < 6) throw 'error';
                      }, 7);
           },'multi try should not throw an exception');
 }

 STDOUT OK ... test example

ifError(Object value)

Return type: n/A

Evaluates 'value' to a boolean using the abstract method Toboolean and throws 'value' if it is true. Useful when testing the first argument, error in callbacks. 

 try {
      throw 'this is an error';
 }
 catch (e) {
      assert.ifError(e);
 }

AttributeMetadata

The AttributeMetadata module allows for retrieval and inspection of an attribute's metadata.

When requiring the AttributeMetadata module, a Javascript object will be populated with the attribute’s metadata as properties. By accessing these properties, one can inspect the state of the attribute.

 var attributeMetadata = require('airlift/attributeMetadata');

The following table describes the properties of the Javascript Object returned by the previous code. It returns a property of the attribute if it has a value for that property. If not, returns a default value. The return types are all Java objects.


Property Description
name Returns a String of the name of the attribute, or null.
type Returns a String of the type of the attribute, or 'java.lang.String'.
isPresentable Returns a boolean of whether or not the attribute is presentable, or true.
displayOrder Returns an int of the display order of the attribute, or 1000.
fieldSetName Returns a String of the fieldSetName of the attribute, or ''.
label Returns a String of the label of the attribute, or ''.
pluralLabel Returns a String of the pluralLabel of the attribute, or ''.
displayLength Returns an int of the display length of the attribute, or 32.
inputType Returns a Type of the input type of the attribute, or 'TEXT'.
textAreaRows Returns an int of the number of rows in the text area of the attribute, or 5.
textAreaColumns Returns an int of the number of columns in the text area of the attribute, or 50.
hasFormat Returns a String of the format of the attribute, or '.*'.
readOnly Returns a boolean of whether or not the attribute is read-only, or false.
allowedValues Returns a String array of the values the attribute allows, or {}.
dateTimePattern Returns a String of the date format of the attribute, or "MM-dd-yyyy".
delimiter Returns a String of the delimiter of the attribute, or ','.
isPersistable Returns a boolean of whether or not the attribute is persistable, or true.
maxLength Returns an int of the maximum length of the attribute, or 200.
minLength Returns an int of the minimum length of the attribute, or 0.
isSearchable Returns a boolean of whether or not the attribute is searchable, or false.
isIndexable Returns a boolean of whether or not the attribute is indexable, or false.
isPrimaryKey Returns a boolean of whether or not the attribute is a primary key, or false.
isUniqueKey Returns a boolean of whether or not the attribute is a unique key, or false.
concept Returns a String of the concept of the attribute, or ''.
nullable Returns a boolean of whether or not the attribute is nullable, or false.
immutable Returns a boolean of whether or not the attribute is immutable, or false.
ranged Returns a boolean of whether or not the attribute is ranged, or false.
minValue Returns a String of the minimum value of the attribute, or null.
maxValue Returns a String the maximum value of the attribute, or null.
encrypted Returns a boolean of whether or not the attribute is encrypted, or false.
semanticType Returns a Semantic of the semantic type of the attribute, or 'NONE'.
mapTo Returns the mapTo of the attribute, or null.
mapToMany Returns the mapToMany of the attribute, or null. 

 attributeMetadata.name;                 => 'person'
 attributeMetadata.readOnly;             => true
 attributeMetadata.encrypted;            => false

ResourceMetadata

The ResourceMetadata module allows for retrieval and inspection of a resource's metadata.

When requiring the ResourceMetadata module, a Javascript object will be populated with the resource’s metadata as properties. By accessing these properties, one can inspect the state of the resource.

 var resourceMetadata = require('airlift/resourceMetadata');

The following table describes the properties of the Javascript Object returned by the previous code. Returns a property of the resource if it has a value for that property. If not, returns a default value.


Property Description
isView Returns a boolean of whether or not the attribute is a view, or false.
isPresented Returns a boolean of whether or not the attribute is presented, or true.
isPersisted Returns a boolean of whether or not the attribute is persisted, or true.
isCached Returns a boolean of whether or not the attribute is cached, or true.
isSecured Returns a boolean of whether or not the attribute is secured, or true.
isAudited Returns a boolean of whether or not the attribute is audited, or false.
lookingAt Returns an object of what the attribute is currently looking at, or undefined. 

 resourceMetadata.isView;                => true
 resourceMetadata.isCached;              => false
 resourceMetadata.lookingAt;             => true

ResourceSecurityMetadata

The ResourceSecurityMetadata module allows for retrieval and inspection of a resource's security metadata.

When requiring the ResourceSecurityMetadata module, a Javascript object will be populated with the resource’s security metadata as properties. By accessing these properties, one can inspect the state of the resource’s security.

 var resourceMetadata = require('airlift/resourceMetadata');

The following table describes the properties of the Javascript Object returned by the previous code. It returns a property of the resource if it has a value for that property. If not, returns a default value. The returned properties are Java HashSets of roles that can make requests to the resource.


Property Description
collectRoles Returns an Object containing the roles that can collect this resource, or {'all': 1}.
putRoles Returns an Object containing the roles that can update this resource, or {'all': 1}.
postRoles Returns an Object containing the roles that can create this resource, or {'all': 1}.
headRoles Returns an Object containing the roles that can get this resource, or {'all': 1}.
getRoles Returns an Object containing the roles that can get this resource, or {'all': 1}.
deleteRoles Returns an Object containing the roles that can delete this resource, or {'noone': 1}. 

 resourceSecurityMetadata.collectRoles;       => {'manager': 1, 'employee': 1}
 resourceSecurityMetadata.putRoles;           => {'manager': 1}
 resourceSecurityMetadata.deleteRoles;        => {'noone': 1}
